name: Uranus

descriptions.short: Uranus is a blue-green ice giant that spins on its side! It's very cold and far from the Sun.
descriptions.medium: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and the third-largest in the solar system. It's an ice giant made of water, methane, and ammonia ices surrounding a rocky core. Uranus is unique because it rotates on its side—its axis is tilted 98 degrees. This gives it extreme seasons lasting 21 years each. Uranus has faint rings and at least 27 moons.
descriptions.long: Uranus is an ice giant with a pale blue-green color caused by methane in its atmosphere, which absorbs red light. Unlike gas giants Jupiter and Saturn, Uranus has more 'ices' (water, methane, ammonia) in its composition. The planet's most unusual feature is its extreme axial tilt of 98 degrees, meaning it essentially rolls around the Sun on its side. This may have been caused by a massive collision early in the solar system's history. Uranus has a faint ring system and at least 27 known moons, all named after characters from Shakespeare and Alexander Pope. The planet has the coldest planetary atmosphere in the solar system, reaching -224°C. Uranus was the first planet discovered with a telescope, found by William Herschel in 1781.

temperature.description: Coldest planetary atmosphere in the solar system

axialTilt.description: Extreme tilt means Uranus rotates on its side

surfacePressure.description: No solid surface; pressure increases with depth

atmosphere.description: Uranus's atmosphere is composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, with about 2.3% methane. The methane absorbs red light, giving Uranus its distinctive blue-green color. The atmosphere is very cold and relatively featureless compared to Jupiter and Saturn, though recent observations have revealed more cloud activity than previously thought.

features.name: Cloud Bands
features.description: Faint bands and occasional bright clouds in the atmosphere
features.significance: Much less prominent than Jupiter or Saturn due to lower temperatures and less internal heat

surface.terrain: No solid surface—atmosphere transitions to icy mantle and rocky core
surface.composition: Hydrogen and helium atmosphere surrounding an icy mantle of water, methane, and ammonia, with a rocky core

majorMoons.name: Miranda
majorMoons.description: Miranda has one of the most bizarre and varied surfaces in the solar system, with huge canyons, terraced layers, and a patchwork appearance suggesting it was shattered and reassembled.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after Miranda from Shakespeare's 'The Tempest'
majorMoons.features: Bizarre patchwork surface, huge canyons, terraced layers

majorMoons.name: Ariel
majorMoons.description: Ariel has the brightest surface of Uranus's moons, with valleys, ridges, and evidence of past geological activity.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after a spirit in Shakespeare's 'The Tempest' and Alexander Pope's 'The Rape of the Lock'
majorMoons.features: Bright surface, valleys, ridges, past geological activity

majorMoons.name: Umbriel
majorMoons.description: Umbriel is the darkest of Uranus's major moons, with an ancient, heavily cratered surface.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after a character in Alexander Pope's 'The Rape of the Lock'

majorMoons.name: Titania
majorMoons.description: The largest moon of Uranus, with a surface showing evidence of past geological activity including large canyons.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after the queen of the fairies in Shakespeare's 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'
majorMoons.features: Largest Uranian moon, large canyons, past geological activity

majorMoons.name: Oberon
majorMoons.description: The second-largest and outermost major moon of Uranus, with a heavily cratered surface and possible ancient volcanic activity.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after the king of the fairies in Shakespeare's 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'
majorMoons.features: Second-largest, heavily cratered, possible ancient volcanism

minorMoons.name: Bianca
minorMoons.mythology: From Shakespeare's 'The Taming of the Shrew'

minorMoons.name: Belinda
minorMoons.mythology: From Alexander Pope's 'The Rape of the Lock'

minorMoons.name: Margaret

roman.namedAfter: Uranus, the Latinized form of the Greek god Ouranos
roman.origin: Named after the primordial Greek god of the sky, breaking the pattern of using Roman god names
roman.story: Uranus (Ouranos) was the primordial god of the sky in Greek mythology. He was born from Gaia (Earth) and became her husband. Together they produced the Titans, Cyclopes, and Hecatoncheires. Uranus imprisoned some of his children in Tartarus, angering Gaia. She convinced their son Cronus (Saturn) to castrate Uranus with a sickle, overthrowing him. From Uranus's blood and severed genitals came the Furies, Giants, and Aphrodite.
roman.culturalSignificance: Uranus represents the first generation of gods in Greek mythology—the primordial deities who embodied fundamental aspects of the cosmos. His overthrow by Cronus began the succession of divine rulers.
roman.symbolism: Sky, heavens, primordial creation, cosmic order, masculine principle

indian.origin: In modern Indian astronomy, Uranus is called Varuna after the Vedic god of the sky and cosmic order. Traditionally, only five planets (visible to naked eye) were recognized in Vedic astrology.
indian.characteristics: Varuna is one of the oldest Vedic deities, originally the supreme god of the cosmic order (Rta), sky, and waters. He is the keeper of cosmic law and divine justice.
indian.story: Varuna is one of the Adityas (solar deities) and was originally the supreme deity in early Vedic religion before being supplanted by Indra. Varuna is the guardian of the cosmic order and punisher of those who violate sacred law. He is all-seeing, with a thousand eyes, and knows all secrets.
indian.culturalSignificance: While Uranus is not part of traditional Navagraha (nine celestial deities), modern Indian astronomy adopted the name Varuna for this planet, connecting it to the ancient sky god.
indian.symbolism: Sky, cosmic order, law, justice, waters, omniscience, divine authority

chinese.name: 天王星 (Tiānwángxīng)
chinese.origin: Named in modern times when Western astronomy was introduced to China
chinese.characteristics: The Chinese name reflects Uranus's association with the sky and heavens, similar to the Greek Ouranos.
chinese.culturalSignificance: As a modern discovery (1781), Uranus was not part of traditional Chinese astronomy's Five Planets system. The name was created to fit Chinese cosmological concepts when Western astronomy was adopted.

mythology.note: Uranus was discovered in 1781, long after ancient mythological traditions were established. Therefore, Babylonian, Egyptian, and Norse mythologies did not have associations with this planet. Modern names in various languages were created based on the Greek god Ouranos or similar sky deities.

formation.description: Uranus formed about 4.6 billion years ago in the outer solar system. Its unusual axial tilt suggests it was struck by a massive object (possibly Earth-sized) early in its history, knocking it onto its side. This collision may have also affected its internal heat flow, making Uranus colder than Neptune despite being closer to the Sun.

discovery.description: Uranus was the first planet discovered with a telescope. Herschel initially thought it was a comet, but later observations confirmed it was a new planet. This discovery doubled the known size of the solar system.

missions.name: Voyager 2
missions.status: Completed Uranus phase, now in interstellar space
missions.description: Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus, making a close flyby in 1986.
majorAchievements: Studied the planet's magnetic field (found to be tilted 60 degrees from rotation axis)
Captured first close-up images of Uranus and its moons

exploration.futureMissions: Several missions to Uranus have been proposed but none are currently approved

comparisonToEarth.atmosphere: Mostly hydrogen and helium with methane

interestingFacts.sidewaysPlanet: Uranus rotates on its side with an axial tilt of 98 degrees, likely caused by a massive collision early in solar system history. This means its poles experience 42 years of continuous sunlight followed by 42 years of darkness.
interestingFacts.firstTelescopeDiscovery: Uranus was the first planet discovered with a telescope by William Herschel in 1781, doubling the known size of the solar system.
interestingFacts.coldestAtmosphere: Despite not being the farthest planet from the Sun, Uranus has the coldest planetary atmosphere, reaching -224°C. This is because it has very little internal heat.
interestingFacts.shakespeareanMoons: All of Uranus's 27 moons are named after characters from works by William Shakespeare and Alexander Pope, breaking from the tradition of using Greek and Roman mythology.
interestingFacts.faintRings: Uranus has 13 known rings, discovered in 1977. They are much darker and fainter than Saturn's rings, made of dark particles.
interestingFacts.tiltedMagneticField: Uranus's magnetic field is tilted 60 degrees from its rotation axis and offset from the planet's center, creating a very unusual magnetosphere.
interestingFacts.onlyOneVisit: Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus, making a flyby in 1986. No other missions have visited since.
interestingFacts.extremeSeasons: Due to its extreme tilt, each season on Uranus lasts about 21 Earth years, with one pole facing the Sun continuously while the other is in darkness.
